document.masterDocTitle: A new genus of hahniid spiders from Far East Asia (Araneae: Hahniidae)

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: A new genus of hahniid spiders from Far East Asia (Araneae: Hahniidae)

figureCitation.captionText-0: FIGURES 1 – 5. Habitus and copulatory organs of Pacifantistea ovtchinnikovi sp. n. 1 – 2 Habitus (1 male; 2 female); 3 Female abdomen, ventral; 4 – 5 Male palp (4 ventral; 5 retrolateral). Abbreviations: Eb — embolic base; Et — tip of embolus; Pa — patellar spur; Sl — seminal loop; Ta — tibial apophysis.
figureCitation.captionText-1: FIGURES 6 – 11. Somatic characters of Pacifantistea ovtchinnikovi sp. n. (6, 11), Neoantistea magna (7, 10) and N. quelpartensis (8 – 9). 6 a, 7 Male mouth parts, ventral; 6 b Male tarsus I, prolateral; 8 Male prosoma, ventral; 9 Male habitus, showing long legs; 10 Female, fronto-lateral, showing stridulatory files (detail in inset); 11 Female prosoma, frontal. Arrows in Fig. 6 b indicating tarsal spines, in Figs 7 – 8 enlarged base of endite. Abbreviations: Sc — scutum; St — strong tooth; Sf — stridulatory file.
figureCitation.captionText-2: FIGURES 12 – 16. Male palp of Pacifantistea ovtchinnikovi sp. n. (12 retrolateral; 13 ventral; 14 patellar spur and tibia, retrolateral; 15 terminal part, ventro-distal; 16 terminal part, ventro-retrolateral). Abbreviations: Eb — embolic base; Pa — patellar spur; Ta — tibial apophysis.
figureCitation.captionText-3: FIGURES 17 – 25. Epigynes of Pacifantistea ovtchinnikovi sp. n. (17 – 18, 23), Neoantistea magna (19 – 20, 24) and N. quelpartensis (21 – 22, 25) (17, 19, 21, 23 – 25 ventral; 18, 20, 22 dorsal; 17 – 22 after maceration in KOH). Abbreviations: Co — copulatory opening; Id — insemination duct; Sp — spermatheca.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Type material
:
Holotype
3 ( ZMMU ) from RUSSIA , Sakhalin Area , Moneron Island, SE shore near Vostochnyye Isles,
46 ° 14.387 ’N
,
141 ° 15.101 'E
, seashore ‘herbs’,
23.08 . 2001
(Y.M. Marusik).

1173 Ƥ and juv. (shared between AMNH , ISEA , IZCAS , NSMT , SMF , ZMMU , ZMUT ), together with the holotype ; 43, 5Ƥ,

1 juv.
( ZMMU ), Khasan District, Far Eastern Marine Reserve, Matveev Island, 2.07 . 1997 (T.S. Vshivkova). JAPAN , Hokkaido :
11 juv.
including subadult 3 and subadult Ƥ ( TRPM ), Rumoi City, Ôgon-misaki Point, 6.07 . 1984 (N. Tsurusaki).

Etymology . The specific name is a patronym in honour of my late friend and colleague Sergei Ovtchinnikov from Kyrgyzstan , who made a huge contribution to the study of spiders in Central Asia. He alerted me to the difference between the new genus and
Neoantistea
(cf.
Figs 1 –2
, 9 ,
26–27
).

Diagnosis . The new species can be easily distinguished from other East Palaearctic Hahniidae by its large size, lack of stridulatory files and in having the carapace lighter in colour than the abdomen.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURES 1–5. Habitus and copulatory organs of
Pacifantistea ovtchinnikovi
sp. n.
1–2 Habitus (1 male; 2 female); 3 Female abdomen, ventral; 4–5 Male palp (4 ventral; 5 retrolateral). Abbreviations: Eb — embolic base; Et — tip of embolus; Pa — patellar spur; Sl — seminal loop; Ta — tibial apophysis.

FIGURES 6–11. Somatic characters of
Pacifantistea ovtchinnikovi
sp. n.
(6, 11),
Neoantistea magna
(7, 10) and
N. quelpartensis
(8–9). 6a, 7 Male mouth parts, ventral; 6b Male tarsus I, prolateral; 8 Male prosoma, ventral; 9 Male habitus, showing long legs; 10 Female, fronto-lateral, showing stridulatory files (detail in inset); 11 Female prosoma, frontal. Arrows in Fig. 6b indicating tarsal spines, in Figs 7–8 enlarged base of endite. Abbreviations: Sc — scutum; St — strong tooth; Sf — stridulatory file.

FIGURES 12–16. Male palp of
Pacifantistea ovtchinnikovi
sp. n.
(12 retrolateral; 13 ventral; 14 patellar spur and tibia, retrolateral; 15 terminal part, ventro-distal; 16 terminal part, ventro-retrolateral). Abbreviations: Eb — embolic base; Pa — patellar spur; Ta — tibial apophysis.

FIGURES 17–25. Epigynes of
Pacifantistea ovtchinnikovi
sp. n.
(17–18, 23),
Neoantistea magna
(19–20, 24) and
N. quelpartensis
(21–22, 25) (17, 19, 21, 23–25 ventral; 18, 20, 22 dorsal; 17–22 after maceration in KOH). Abbreviations: Co — copulatory opening; Id — insemination duct; Sp — spermatheca.

subSubSection.paragraph: Female. Leg segments of specimen with dimensions: 5.10 , carapace: 2.43 long, 1.83 wide.

Leg Femur Patella Tibia Metatarsus Tarsus Total I 1.93 0.79 1.57 1.57 1.00 6.86 II 1.86 0.77 1.57 1.57 0.93 6.70 III 1.79 0.79 1.43 1.81 1.03 6.85 IV 2.21 0.93 2.00 2.36 1.21 8.71 Male palp as in
Figs 4 –5
,
12– 16
. Femur slightly longer than patella + tibia and longer than cymbium. Patella thicker than the other segments, with long patellar spur ( Pa ). Tibia thin, tibial apophysis ( Ta ) long (longer than tibia), almost straight and perpendicular to the axis of the tibia. Cymbium about twice as long as wide, terminal part (above the bulbus) long, about 1 / 3 of the cymbial length. Tegulum oval, embolus long, filamentous, starting at 6 o’clock, running a loop of approximately 270 ° around the tegulum. Seminal duct forming a small (shallow) loop ( Sl ) on the retrolateral side in the proximal region of the tegulum. Conductor absent.

Epigyne as in Figs 3 , 17–18, 23 . Very simple, with two small copulatory openings ( Co ) in the anterior part of epigynal plate and translucent oval shaped spermatheca midway between the openings and the epigastral fold. Vulva also very simple with transparent, weakly sclerotized insemination ducts ( Id ) running down from the openings into oval shaped spermatheca.

Habitats . All specimens were collected on the seashore among pebbles or on sandy beaches. It is easy to recognize if this species occurs among pebbles due to the characteristic white egg cocoons attached to the stones. Egg sacs look like that figured by
Opell and Beatty ( 1976 : fig. 2 )
. The new species sometimes occurs in large numbers on sandy beaches. In Moneron and on Ketoi Islands one hundred specimens were collected within half an hour by scrubbing (raking up) the sand. Disturbed specimens start to run and became easily visible. Each large sample contained specimens of different age.

Distribution . It is known from the southern region of the Maritime Province, Moneron, South and Middle Kuril Islands, from Petropavlovsk-Kamchatski and western Hokkaido (
Fig. 40
).
P. ovtchinnikovi
sp. n.
was not found in Sakhalin, Paramushir, Onekotan and Shumshu islands, despite being searched for. Its occurrence in the adjacent Korean Peninsula is very likely.
